chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Starting from 3.0.0.Alpha1 version, JBoss set of plugins includes tools for supporting JBoss Portal and JSR-186/JSR-286 portlets. Thus, this guide is intended to explain you how to get started and manage JBoss Portlet Tools.

section.title: Creating and Deploying a Java Portlet
section.para: This chapter shows how to create a Dynamic Web Project, add a Java Portlet to it and deploy it to the JBoss Portal.

section.title: Creating a Web Project with JBoss Portlet Capabilities
section.para: Fallow the next procedure to create a Web project with JBoss Portlet capabilities pointed to the JBoss Portal runtime.

listitem.para: Go to File > New > Dynamic Web Project if you are in the Web perspective or File > New > Other > Web > Dynamic Web Project in any other perspective. The New Dynamic Web Project wizard appears.

figure.title: New Dynamic Web Project

listitem.para: Specify the name of the project.
Click New in the Target Runtime area to create a JBoss Portal runtime. Choose JBoss Community > JBoss 4.2 Runtime and select the Create a new local server check box below. Click Next.

figure.title: New Server Runtime

listitem.para: The New Server Runtime Environment wizard appears. In the Name field, type JBoss Portal 2.7 Runtime, and then use the Browse button to point to the location of JBoss Portal + JBoss AS extracted. Click Next to proceed.

figure.title: New Server Runtime Environment

listitem.para: At this point a new JBoss Server instance will be created. On the next page you can verify the runtime information defined. If something is incorrect, press Back to return to the previous wizard page. Click Finish.

figure.title: Target Server

listitem.para: Click Modify in the Configuration area to enable a portlet facet for the project.

figure.title: Setting the Project Configuration

listitem.para: In the Project Facets dialog, check JBoss Core Portlet and press OK .

figure.title: Enabling the JBoss Core Portlet Facet

note.title: Note:
note.para:
If the portlet libraries aren't available in the runtime you targeted,
JBoss Portlets facets will be hidden on this page.
To make them always visible no matter what the runtime is set, you should enable the appropriate option in JBoss Portlet Preferences.

listitem.para: The Java and Web Module pages are for configuring Java and Web modules in the project. Here all values are set, so leave everything as it is.
The last wizard page will ask you to add JBoss Portlet capabilities to the project. Select Portlet Target Runtime Provider and click Finish to complete the project creation.

figure.title: Including the Portlet Libraries Provided by Target Runtime

note.title: Note:
note.para: All types available under Portlet Implementation Library are fully described in the Wiki article at: http://www.jboss.org/community/wiki/PortletFacetLibraries.

section.para: As the result, JBoss Portlet Tools adds JBoss Core Portlet facet to the project, creates an empty portlet.xml file and adds the JBoss Portlet library to the project classpath.

figure.title: Portlet Project Structure Overview

section.title: Adding a Java Portlet to a Web Project
section.para: At the previous section you have created a web project with JBoss Portlet capabilities. The next steps will show you how to add a new Java portlet to the project.

listitem.para: Right-click the project and follow to New > Other > JBoss Tools Web > Portlet > Java Portlet.

figure.title: New Java Portlet

listitem.para: The Create Portlet wizard starts (for information about the wizard options, see "Java Portlet Wizard" in the guide reference). The wizard fills in the Project and Source Folder fields for you. You should specify a Java package and a class name (for instance, org.example and TestPortlet). Then click Next .

figure.title: Specifying Class File Destination

listitem.para: You may leave the next three pages with default values, on the last one hit Finish.

section.para: Once a Java portlet is created, new resources are added to the project structure: a Java portlet class (TestPortlet.java), default-object.xml and portlet-instances.xml files and the portlet.xml descriptor is updated as well.

figure.title: Structure of the Project with a Java Portlet

section.para: Thus, now the project is ready to be built and deployed.

section.title: Deploying a Portlet to JBoss Portal
section.para: You can deploy a portlet project in the way you deploy any other web application.

listitem.para: Right-click the project and do Run As > Run On Server. The Run On Server wizard starts.

figure.title: Running the Java Portlet on Server

listitem.para: Select JBoss Portal 2.7 Server created before and click Next.
On the Add and Remove page move the created project to the right and click Finish.

figure.title: Deploying the Portlet Application

listitem.para: It will deploy the portlet application and start JBoss AS.
Use the http://localhost:8080/portal/portal/default/default URL to see your portlet in the browser.

figure.title: Java Portlet in the Browser Window

chapter.title: Reference
chapter.para: This chapter includes detailed reference information about JBoss Portlet Tools.

section.title: JBoss Portlet Descriptors
section.para: In order to a web project with portlets could be deployed to JBoss Portal, it should include certain descriptors. The next table lists and describes these configuration files.

row.entry: The mandatory portlet descriptor defined by the JSR-168 Portlet Specification. It is used during deployment.
The optional JBoss Portal specific descriptor. It allows to create a portlet instance from a portlet class definition.
The optional JBoss Portal specific descriptor. It helps define the layout of the portal.
The optional JBoss Portal specific descriptor. It allows to use JBoss specific functionality within a portlet application.

section.para: For more detail information about each descriptor, see "Portlet Descriptors" in Chapter 6, "JBoss Portal Reference Guide".

section.title: JSF/Seam Portlet Wizard
section.para: The JSF/Seam Portlet wizard, that is merged into one JSF and Seam Portlet wizards, helps you create a JSF/Seam portlet that uses the JBoss Portlet Bridge libraries. The default values in this wizard depend on the configuration set for the project. For instance, if you set the JSF configuration, the default values in this wizard will be as for a JSF portlet.
The JSF/Seam Portlet wizard could be started from the File or context menu of your project by following to New > Other > JBoss Tools Web > Portlet > JSF/Seam Portlet.

section.title: JBoss Portlet Preferences
section.para: To open JBoss Portlet Preferences property sheet, go to Window > Preferences and then JBoss Tools > JBoss Portlet.

figure.title: JBoss Runtime Preferences

section.para: The Check runtimes for Portlet Components option makes the JBoss Portlet functionality always visible no matter what the runtime is set. By default the option is checked.
